content: Example and Best Practice # Shared Mutable State # Unsafe Use public class Counter { private int count = 0; public void increment() { count++; } public int getCount() { return count; } } Better Practice public class Counter { private int count = 0; public synchronized void increment() { count++; } public synchronized int getCount() { return count; } } - Adding `synchronized` on the methods ensure each method

title: TLS Handshake: Server Hello
content:
TLS Handshake: Server Hello # After a client sends the ClientHello message to initiate a secure connection, the server responds with ServerHello. This message finalizes the parameters needed to establish an encrypted session, and it’s the server’s way of saying:
“Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve selected from your offers. Let‚Äôs proceed securely.”
In this post, we‚Äôll break down the ServerHello message, how to view it, and what its key components mean.
Step 1: Capture ServerHello Using OpenSSL # To view the TLS handshake, including ServerHello, use:
openssl s_client -connect www.google.com:443 -servername www.google.com -msg Once connected, look for:
<<< TLS 1.3 Handshake [length ****], ServerHello To analyze the hex data, first store it in a file called server_hello.hex:
01 00 01 2d 03 03 a1 c6 ed 3f 78 88 21 0c 32 40 ... Now, use Python to parse it. Create file tls-parser.py:
from scapy.all import * load_layer("tls") with open("server_hello.hex", "r") as file: hex_str = file.read().replace(r"\s+", "") pkt = TLSServerHello(bytes.fromhex(hex_str)) pkt.show() Run the Python script to view the ServerClient message:
python3 tls-parser.py Step 2: Key Contents of ServerHello (TLS 1.3) # Here‚Äôs a real parsed example and what each field means:
Field Purpose Version The version of TLS chosen by the server (usually TLS 1.3) Random Bytes Server-generated random number, used in key generation Session ID Optional field used for session resumption (32 bytes here) Cipher Suite The encryption algorithm selected by the server (e.g., CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256) Extensions Additional fields, described below Extensions in ServerHello
TLS 1.3 simplifies and minimizes the extensions in ServerHello. Here’s what we typically see:
üîê Key Share
Contains the server’s public key and the group (e.g., x25519) used to generate it. Used with the client‚Äôs key to derive the shared symmetric key for encryption. üî¢ Supported Versions
Indicates that the server selected TLS 1.3. This confirms the TLS version chosen from the client‚Äôs supported list. Example: TLS 1.3 ServerHello
###[ TLS Handshake - Server Hello ]### msgtype = server_hello msglen = 118 version = TLS 1.2 gmt_unix_time= Thu, 02 Jan 2031 02:05:04 (1925085904) random_bytes= 77759f2424f6ad... sidlen = 32 sid = b'\xe4\xff\x88,\xe6\xc7r\xcb...' cipher = TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256 comp = null extlen = 46 \ext \ |###[ TLS Extension - Key Share (for ServerHello) ]### | type = key_share | len = 36 | \server_share\ | |###[ Key Share Entry ]### | | group = x25519 | | kxlen = 32 | | key_exchange= 02c394022ce15ba... |###[ TLS Extension - Supported Versions (for ServerHello) ]### | type = supported_versions | len = 2 | version = TLS 1.3 Summary # The ServerHello is the server‚Äôs response to the client‚Äôs handshake offer. It:
Selects the final TLS version, cipher, and key parameters Sends the server’s key share (group and key) so that both sides can compute a shared encryption key Confirms the protocol version with extensions like supported_versions Together with the ClientHello, this message lays the foundation for encrypted HTTPS communication using a symmetric key agreed upon securely during the handshake.

title: HTTP Headers Part 4: Cache Validation
content:
üìò Lesson: HTTP Cache Validation ‚Äì ETag and Last-Modified with FastAPI # In the previous lesson, we learned how to control whether and how content is cached using Cache-Control. In this lesson, we focus on cache validation, which allows the server to determine whether a client’s cached response is still valid. If so, it can return a lightweight 304 Not Modified instead of resending the full resource.
We’ll cover how ETag and Last-Modified headers work, how clients use their corresponding validation headers (If-None-Match and If-Modified-Since), and how servers determine which one takes precedence. We’ll also walk through a complete FastAPI example and test it using the browser console.
üîç Why Validate Cached Content? # Cache validation reduces unnecessary data transfer and accelerates response times. Rather than re-downloading content that hasn’t changed, the client asks the server:
“Has this changed since I last received it?”
If the server determines it has not changed, it returns:
HTTP/1.1 304 Not Modified This saves bandwidth and improves speed.
üîó What Are ETag and Last-Modified? # When responding to a request, a server can include one or both of the following headers to help the client validate the content later:
üîπ ETag (Entity Tag)
A unique identifier for the content (usually a hash or version string). If the content changes, the ETag value changes. The client stores this value and uses it in the If-None-Match header on future requests. Example: ETag: "abc123" üîπ Last-Modified
A timestamp indicating when the resource was last changed. Sent in the Last-Modified header. The client uses this value in a future If-Modified-Since header. Example: Last-Modified: Wed, 10 Apr 2024 12:00:00 GMT When sending a request, the client can include one or both following headers to allow the server to validate the cache:
üî∏ If-None-Match
Sent by the client to check if the server’s current ETag differs from what the client has. If the values match, the server returns 304 Not Modified. Example: If-None-Match: "abc123" üî∏ If-Modified-Since
Sent by the client to check if the resource has changed since the given timestamp. If it has not, the server responds with 304 Not Modified. Example: If-Modified-Since: Wed, 10 Apr 2024 12:00:00 GMT üîÑ How Do These Headers Work Together? # Header Role Sent By Paired With ETag Version ID Server If-None-Match If-None-Match Validator Client ETag Last-Modified Timestamp Server If-Modified-Since If-Modified-Since Validator Client Last-Modified üß≠ Precedence Rules # If both If-None-Match and If-Modified-Since are present: The server must evaluate If-None-Match first. If it matches ‚Üí return 304 Not Modified If it does not match, evaluate If-Modified-Since If the timestamp is still valid ‚Üí return 304 Not Modified Otherwise ‚Üí return new content (200 OK) üí° ETag is generally more precise than Last-Modified and preferred for fine-grained cache validation.
üõ†Ô∏è FastAPI Hands-On Example # In this example, we dynamically generate a response string that includes a counter updated every 10 seconds. The server sets both an ETag (based on content hash) and a Last-Modified timestamp. The client can use either or both to validate the cached content.
Change directory to 03-http-headers and create a new Python file cache-validation.py:
cd 03-http-headers touch cache-validation.py Paste in the following Python code:
from fastapi import FastAPI, Request, Response from fastapi.responses import JSONResponse from datetime import datetime import hashlib app = FastAPI() @app.get("/validate") def validate_cache(request: Request): # Calculate counter and last_modified from current time now = datetime.utcnow() epoch_seconds = int(now.timestamp()) counter = epoch_seconds // 100 content = f"This is the cached data #{counter}" last_modified = datetime.utcfromtimestamp(counter * 100) etag = hashlib.md5(content.encode()).hexdigest() # 1. ETag validation if_none_match = request.headers.get("if-none-match") if if_none_match == etag: return Response( status_code=304, headers={"X-Cache-Validated-By": "etag"} ) # 2. Last-Modified validation if_modified_since = request.headers.get("if-modified-since") if if_modified_since: since = datetime.strptime(if_modified_since, "%a, %d %b %Y %H:%M:%S GMT") if last_modified <= since: return Response( status_code=304, headers={"X-Cache-Validated-By": "last-modified"} ) headers = { "ETag": etag, "Last-Modified": last_modified.strftime("%a, %d %b %Y %H:%M:%S GMT"), "Cache-Control": "public, max-age=0" } return JSONResponse({ "data": content }, headers=headers) üß™ Test It Out Using the Browser Console # You can test cache validation directly in the browser using Chrome DevTools:
Open Chrome DevTools (F12) Go to the Console tab Step 1: Make an Initial Request
Run below command in the Console:
fetch("http://localhost:8000/validate").then(res => { console.log("ETag:", res.headers.get("etag")); console.log("Last-Modified:", res.headers.get("last-modified")); console.log("Validated By:", res.headers.get("X-Cache-Validated-By")); const status = res.status; console.log("Response Status Code:", status); if (res.status === 200) { res.json().then(data => { console.log("Response Content:", data); }); } }); Console logs:
ETag: 8fc1ceef992cc55a62591b537d1ec7fa Last-Modified: Mon, 14 Apr 2025 01:30:00 GMT Validated By: etag Response Status Code: 200 Response Content: {data: 'This is the cached data #17445942'} The server will:
Return 200 status code Return content hash in ETag header Return content modified timestamp in Last-Modified header Step 2: Validate with If-None-Match
Substitute <your-etag-value> in below command with ETag from the response in last step:
fetch("http://localhost:8000/validate", { headers: { "If-None-Match": "<your-etag-value>" } }).then(res => { console.log("ETag:", res.headers.get("etag")); console.log("Last-Modified:", res.headers.get("last-modified")); console.log("Validated By:", res.headers.get("X-Cache-Validated-By")); const status = res.status; console.log("Response Status Code:", status); if (res.status === 200) { res.json().then(data => { console.log("Response Content:", data); }); } }); You should see console logs as below. If the server returns 200, it means that the content has been updated. Rerun same command using ETag value in latest 200 response.
ETag: null Last-Modified: null Validated By: etag Response Status Code: 304 The server will:
Return 304 status code Indicate the cache is validated by ETag Step 3: Validate with If-Modified-Since
Substitute <your-last-modified-date> in below command with Last-Modified from the response in last step:
fetch("http://localhost:8000/validate", { headers: { "If-Modified-Since": "<your-last-modified-date>" } }).then(res => { console.log("ETag:", res.headers.get("etag")); console.log("Last-Modified:", res.headers.get("last-modified")); console.log("Validated By:", res.headers.get("X-Cache-Validated-By")); const status = res.status; console.log("Response Status Code:", status); if (res.status === 200) { res.json().then(data => { console.log("Response Content:", data); }); } }); Console logs:
ETag: null Last-Modified: null Validated By: last-modified Response Status Code: 304 The server will:
Return 304 status code Indicate the cache is validated by Last-Modified Step 4: Use Both Headers Together
fetch("http://localhost:8000/validate", { headers: { "If-None-Match": "<your-etag-value>", "If-Modified-Since": "<your-last-modified-date>" } }).then(res => { console.log("ETag:", res.headers.get("etag")); console.log("Last-Modified:", res.headers.get("last-modified")); console.log("Validated By:", res.headers.get("X-Cache-Validated-By")); const status = res.status; console.log("Response Status Code:", status); if (res.status === 200) { res.json().then(data => { console.log("Response Content:", data); }); } }); ETag: null Last-Modified: null Validated By: etag Response Status Code: 304 The server will:
Return 304 if the ETag matches If not, check timestamp If still valid, return 304 Otherwise, return updated content (200 OK)

title: I/O  Model Summary
content:
I/O Model # We have discussed some I/O models, like blocking I/O model and non-blocking I/O model. These two I/O models have their own problems which are low efficient.
Then I introduce another I/O model Multiplexing which utilizes Selector to monitor registered keys and handle operations in a batch. This model provides high efficiency and handles multiple operations like accept (client connection) and read concurrently.
In this post, I will introduce two more I/O models, synchronous and asynchronous.
Synchronous I/O Model # Definition # In the synchronous I/O model, the thread initiates the input or output operations and then it is blocked until the operation is completed. The thread remains inactive and can not perform any other tasks during this time. The thread resumes its executions after the operation has finished
Key factors # Only one thread is involved to initiate the operation and get the result The thread is idle or blocked when waiting for the operation completing Linear execution flow Example # Code
public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException { FileChannel fc = FileChannel.open(Paths.get("/path/to/file/data.txt"), StandardOpenOption.READ); ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.allocate(16); fc.read(buffer); buffer.flip(); ByteBufferReader.readAll(buffer); } Execution result
16:18:51.605 [main] DEBUG com.whatsbehind.netty_.utility.ByteBufferReader - Hello World! The example of synchronous I/O model is quite straight forward and easy. Only one thread is involved and the thread is blocked at blocking method fc.read(buffer) until data is loaded from the disk and copied to memories
Asynchronous I/O Model # Definition # In asynchronous I/O model, when a thread initiates an I/O operation, it is not blocked and wait until the operation completes. Instead, the thread continues to execute, and another thread works on the I/O operation. Once the operation is complete, the initiating thread will be notified through mechanism like callbacks
Key factors # Multiple threads are involved.
One thread is called main thread, which initiates the I/O operation, and it is not blocked during the operation. Instead, it continues to execute other tasks. Another thread is called working thread, its main task is to complete the I/O operation and calls back the main thread when the operation is complete. Main thread is not blocked
Concurrency: Main thread can handle multiple I/O operations concurrently
Example # Code
public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException, InterruptedException { AsynchronousFileChannel afc = AsynchronousFileChannel.open(Paths.get("/path/to/file/data.txt"), StandardOpenOption.READ); ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.allocate(16); log.debug("Start reading..."); afc.read(buffer, 0, buffer, new CompletionHandler<Integer, ByteBuffer>() { @Override public void completed(Integer integer, ByteBuffer buffer) { buffer.flip(); ByteBufferReader.readAll(buffer); } @Override public void failed(Throwable throwable, ByteBuffer buffer) { throwable.printStackTrace(); } }); log.debug("Finish reading..."); Thread.sleep(1000); } In afc.read(...) method of the async file channel, I pass in a callback object which has two methods completed and failed which are invoked by the working thread when the read operation completes or throws. I insert three logs before and after the read method and inside the completed method In the end of the code snippet, I force the main thread to sleep 1s. Because the working thread is a daemon thread, it terminates when main thread finishes all tasks. Sleeping 1s allows the work thread to complete Execution result
16:34:14.824 [main] DEBUG com.whatsbehind.netty_.nio.asynchronous_.CallBackFileReader - Start reading... 16:34:14.826 [main] DEBUG com.whatsbehind.netty_.nio.asynchronous_.CallBackFileReader - Finish reading... 16:34:14.828 [Thread-0] DEBUG com.whatsbehind.netty_.utility.ByteBufferReader - Hello World! Two threads are involved, main thread (main) and working thread (Thread-0) Logs Start reading... and Finish reading... are printed first and the thread is main thread. That means after initiating the read operation afc.read(...), the read operation is allocated to the working thread and the main thread is not blocked but continues to execute other tasks The data read from the disk later is printed and its executing thread is the working thread. That means the two threads are running concurrently Is Future asynchronous? # Code
public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException, InterruptedException, ExecutionException { AsynchronousFileChannel afc = AsynchronousFileChannel.open(Paths.get("/path/to/file/data.txt"), StandardOpenOption.READ); ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.allocate(16); log.debug("Start reading..."); Future<Integer> future = afc.read(buffer, 0); // Blocking method: main thread is blocked here until read operation completes future.get(); buffer.flip(); ByteBufferReader.readAll(buffer); log.debug("Finish reading..."); Thread.sleep(1000); } Instead of utilizing callbacks to notify the main thread. We can use Future object to get the data after the read operation After calling afc.read(...), I invoke a blocking method future.get() to let the main thread wait here until the read operation completes. During this time, the working thread is working on the read operation and the main thread is blocked Execution result
16:46:47.948 [main] DEBUG com.whatsbehind.netty_.nio.asynchronous_.FutureFileReader - Start reading... 16:46:47.952 [main] DEBUG com.whatsbehind.netty_.utility.ByteBufferReader - Hello World! 16:46:47.952 [main] DEBUG com.whatsbehind.netty_.nio.asynchronous_.FutureFileReader - Finish reading... The above code works as synchronous I/O model. Codes are executed like a linear way and all logs are printed in the main thread Is it asynchronous?
In my opinion, NO! This way has two threads involved, but comparing with synchronous I/O model, main thread only transfers its read job to the working thread. Main thread is still blocked at method future.get(), and it can’t execute other tasks. Further more, comparing with synchronous I/O model, this way has one more thread involved but doesn’t allow main to execute multiple tasks concurrently.

title: Lesson 5: Docker Networking
content:
üß∞ Docker Mastery Course ‚Äì Lesson 5 # üì° Understanding Docker Networking # Welcome to Lesson 5 of the Docker Mastery Course! In this lesson, you’ll learn how Docker networking works, how to expose container services, and how containers communicate with each other and with the outside world.
üéØ Goal # By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll understand how to:
Expose container ports to your host machine Use Docker bridge networks Connect multiple containers Resolve container names using Docker DNS Access public internet domains from within containers üìö Concepts # What Is Docker Networking? # Docker creates virtual networks that allow containers to:
Communicate with each other securely Be isolated from or connected to external systems Default Docker Network Types # Network Mode Description bridge Default for user-created containers; provides isolation and DNS resolution within the same network host Shares the host‚Äôs network stack (Linux only) none Disables all networking overlay Connects containers across multiple Docker hosts (advanced use cases) This lesson focuses on the bridge network, the default and most commonly used setup.
üìÅ Hands-On Practice # ‚úÖ Step 1: Expose a Container to the Host # Run a public-facing container and map its internal port to your machine:
docker run -d --name mynginx -p 8080:80 nginx -d: runs the container in detached (background) mode --name mynginx: names the container -p 8080:80: maps host port 8080 to container port 80 Visit http://localhost:8080 in your browser to view the Nginx welcome page.
To clean up:
docker stop mynginx docker rm mynginx ‚úÖ Step 2: Create a Custom Docker Network # Create a user-defined bridge network:
docker network create demo-net Verify it exists:
docker network ls A custom network like this allows containers to communicate by name through Docker‚Äôs internal DNS resolver.
‚úÖ Step 3: Connect Two Containers by Name # Start an Nginx container in the custom network:
docker run -d --name web --network demo-net nginx -d: runs the container in detached mode --name web: names the container “web” --network demo-net: connects the container to the custom network nginx: the image being used Now run an Alpine container in the same network and ping the Nginx container:
docker run -it --rm --network demo-net alpine ping web -it: opens an interactive terminal session --rm: automatically removes the container after it exits --network demo-net: connects the container to the same network alpine: the image used (a lightweight Linux distro) ping web: runs the ping command inside the container, using web as the hostname üß† Why does this work? When containers are on the same user-defined network, Docker injects a custom DNS configuration. This allows containers to resolve each other by name. In this case, web is resolved to the internal IP address of the Nginx container.
‚úÖ Step 4: Ping a Public Domain from a Container # Containers can access the internet by default:
docker run -it --rm alpine ping google.com Docker uses NAT (Network Address Translation) to route outbound traffic Public DNS queries like google.com are forwarded to your host‚Äôs DNS resolver This works even on the default bridge network ‚ùó Containers can access the internet by default, but the internet cannot access containers unless you explicitly expose ports (-p) or configure a reverse proxy.
üèÉÔ∏è Checkpoint # By now, you‚Äôve learned how to:
Expose container services to your host Create and use custom Docker networks Connect containers and communicate using container names Understand how Docker’s DNS system works Access external resources from inside a container üéâ Great job! You‚Äôre now equipped to build multi-container apps that communicate efficiently and securely.
üìÜ What‚Äôs Next? # Lesson 6: Data Persistence with Volumes Learn how to manage persistent data in Docker, make data survive container restarts, and understand the difference between volumes and bind mounts.
Stay tuned!

title: TLS Handshake: Certificate
content:
TLS Handshake: Certificate # What is a TLS Certificate? # During the TLS handshake, the server sends its certificate to the client to prove its identity. This certificate contains the server‚Äôs public key and information about who issued the certificate (a Certificate Authority). The client uses this certificate to verify that it’s really talking to the correct server, and then uses the public key to help create a secure, encrypted connection.
The whole purpose of Certificate is to authenticate server identity
View the Server Certificate # Use OpenSSL to connect to a server and retrieve its certificate:
openssl s_client -connect www.google.com:443 -servername www.google.com In the output, look for the section that starts with:
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- ... -----END CERTIFICATE----- This is the server‚Äôs TLS certificate, including -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- and -----END CERTIFICATE-----.
Save server cert to file server.crt:
openssl s_client -connect www.google.com:443 -servername www.google.com </dev/null | sed -n '/-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----/,/-----END CERTIFICATE-----/p' > server.crt You can inspect the certificate’s contents using:
openssl x509 -in server.crt -text -noout Key fields in the certificate include:
Subject: The domain the certificate is for Issuer: Who issued the certificate (a CA) Validity: Start and end dates Public Key: Used in the handshake to establish secure communication Signature: A hash of the certificate data encrypted by the issuer’s private key Decoded server certificate example
Certificate: Data: Version: 3 (0x2) Serial Number: b9:32:9c:bd:a9:ef:7f:44:12:09:8e:72:2a:68:45:d3 Signature Algorithm: sha256WithRSAEncryption Issuer: C=US, O=Google Trust Services, CN=WR2 Validity Not Before: Mar 20 11:20:31 2025 GMT Not After : Jun 12 11:20:30 2025 GMT Subject: CN=www.google.com Subject Public Key Info: Public Key Algorithm: id-ecPublicKey Public-Key: (256 bit) pub: 04:a7:a6:c6:52:... X509v3 extensions: ... Signature Algorithm: sha256WithRSAEncryption 2c:40:49:11:97... Chain of Certificates # A full certificate chain typically includes:
Leaf Certificate: The server‚Äôs certificate (e.g., server.crt) Intermediate CA Certificates: Certificates used to sign the leaf certificate Root Certificate: Trusted by operating systems or browsers View the Full Certificate Chain Use the following command to view the entire certificate chain:
openssl s_client -connect www.google.com:443 -servername www.google.com -showcerts </dev/null Save Certificates Separately From the output:
Save the first certificate block (from -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- to -----END CERTIFICATE-----) into a file named server.crt. This is the leaf certificate. Save the remaining certificates into a file named chain.pem. These are the intermediate certificates. Download Root Certificates
Download Google’s root certificates:
curl -o roots.pem https://pki.goog/roots.pem Then append them to the chain file:
echo >> chain.pem && cat roots.pem >> chain.pem Verify the Certificate Chain
Now verify the certificate chain:
openssl verify -CAfile chain.pem server.crt If the chain is complete and valid, you’ll see:
server.crt: OK How is One Certificate Verified? # When a client verifies a certificate, it needs to make sure the certificate was truly issued by a trusted authority and hasn’t been tampered with. Here’s how it works:
Use the issuer’s public key (from the next certificate in the chain) to decrypt the signature found in the certificate being verified. This reveals a hash value. Independently compute a hash of the certificate’s “To Be Signed” (TBS) section using the same hash algorithm. Compare the two hashes: If they match, the certificate is confirmed to be authentic and untampered. This method works recursively: the client starts by verifying the server‚Äôs certificate using the intermediate certificate‚Äôs public key, then verifies the intermediate using the next certificate in the chain, and so on until it reaches a root certificate that is already trusted by the client (pre-installed in the OS or browser).

title: Cookie
content:
What is cookie # An HTTP cookie (web cookie, browser cookie) is a small piece of data that a server sends to a user’s web browser. The browser may store the cookie and send it back to the same server with later requests. Typically, an HTTP cookie is used to tell if two requests come from the same browser‚Äîkeeping a user logged in, for example. It remembers stateful information for the stateless HTTP protocol.
Cookies are created by server Cookies are stored in client’s browser Cookies are sent with every request to the same domain (Explain more below) Deprecation of cookie # Cookies were once used for general client-side storage. While this made sense when they were the only way to store data on the client, modern storage APIs are now recommended. Cookies are sent with every request, so they can worsen performance (especially for mobile data connections). Modern APIs for client storage are the Web Storage API (localStorage and sessionStorage) and IndexedDB.
Use case of cookie # Session management Logins, shopping carts, game scores, or anything else the server should remember
Personalization User preferences, themes, and other settings
You visited a weather website and entered your address to get weather information. The server set an address cookie under the domain of the weather website. Next time when you revisit the website, the address cookie will be sent in the request’s header, and the website will show weather information of same address. Tracking Recording and analyzing user behavior (ADs)
How to set cookies # Cookies can be set and modified at the server level using
the Set-Cookie HTTP header, or with JavaScript using document.cookie. After receiving an HTTP request, a server can send one or more Set-Cookie headers with the response. The browser usually stores the cookie and sends it with requests made to the same server inside a Cookie HTTP header.
Set-Cookie and Cookie headers # The Set-Cookie HTTP response header sends cookies from the server to the user agent. A simple cookie is set like this:
Set-Cookie: <cookie-name>=<cookie-value> Example:
HTTP/2.0 200 OK Content-Type: text/html Set-Cookie: yummy_cookie=choco Set-Cookie: tasty_cookie=strawberry [page content] Define the lifecycle of a cookie # The lifetime of a cookie can be defined in two ways:
Session cookies are deleted when the current session ends. The browser defines when the “current session” ends, and some browsers use session restoring when restarting. This can cause session cookies to last indefinitely. Permanent cookies are deleted at a date specified by the Expires attribute, or after a period of time specified by the Max-Age attribute. Example: Set-Cookie: id=a3fWa; Expires=Thu, 31 Oct 2021 07:28:00 GMT; Restrict access to cookies # Secure attribute A cookie with the Secure attribute is only sent to the server with an encrypted request over the HTTPS protocol. HttpOnly attribute A cookie with the HttpOnly attribute is inaccessible to the JavaScript Document.cookie API; it’s only sent to the server. For example, cookies that persist in server-side sessions don’t need to be available to JavaScript and should have the HttpOnly attribute. This precaution helps mitigate cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks. Example: Set-Cookie: id=a3fWa; Expires=Thu, 21 Oct 2021 07:28:00 GMT; Secure; HttpOnly Define where cookies are sent # The Domain and Path attributes define the scope of a cookie: what URLs the cookies should be sent to.
Domain attribute # The Domain attribute specifies which hosts can receive a cookie. If the server does not specify a Domain, the browser defaults the domain to the same host that set the cookie, excluding subdomains. If Domain is specified, then subdomains are always included. Therefore, specifying Domain is less restrictive than omitting it. However, it can be helpful when subdomains need to share information about a user.
For example, if you set Domain=mozilla.org, cookies are available on domains like
mozilla.orgdeveloper.mozilla.org If the the cookie was set by server with domain example.com, and no domain attribute was specified. Then the cookie will only be send to domain example.com.
Path attribute # The Path attribute indicates a URL path that must exist in the requested URL in order to send the Cookie header. The ("/") character is considered a directory separator, and subdirectories match as well. For example, if you set Path=/docs, these request paths match:
/docs/docs//docs/Web//docs/Web/HTTP But these request paths don’t:
//docsets/fr/docs TODO # There are still some other attributes and concepts regarding cookie, will dive deeper later is necessary Attach some picture about Set-Cookie and Cookie headers, and attributes of a cookie Dive deeper for HttpOnly attribute Reference # Cookie Definition Nice YouTube video

title: Lesson 6: Docker Volumes
content:
üíæ Docker Mastery Course ‚Äì Lesson 6 # üì¶ Data Persistence with Volumes and Bind Mounts # Welcome to Lesson 6 of the Docker Mastery Course! In this lesson, you’ll learn how to persist data in Docker containers using volumes and bind mounts, and understand the differences between them.
üéØ Goal # By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:
Understand why container data is ephemeral by default Use volumes to persist data across container lifecycles Use bind mounts to sync data between host and container Explain the differences between volumes and bind mounts clearly Understand how multiple containers can share the same volume Know how Docker handles (or doesn‚Äôt handle) concurrent writes üìò Concepts # 1. Why Data Persistence Matters # Docker containers are designed to be ephemeral ‚Äî meaning:
If a container is deleted or restarted, any data written inside it is lost. This makes it hard to store logs, databases, or application-generated files. To solve this, Docker supports two methods:
Method Description Volumes Docker-managed persistent storage. Recommended for most cases. Bind mounts User-specified paths on the host. Great for development workflows. 2. Volume vs Bind Mount: What’s the Difference? # Feature Volume Bind Mount Managed by Docker ‚úÖ Yes ‚ùå No ‚Äî user defines path Host path visible ‚ùå Abstracted (Docker manages it) ‚úÖ Directly maps to a host folder Created by docker volume create or automatically User simply provides a path Location /var/lib/docker/volumes/... (Linux/Mac) Anywhere on the host Use case Databases, persistent files Syncing source code in development üîé Are bind mounts like symlinks? Not quite ‚Äî they‚Äôre actual kernel-level filesystem mounts. Bind mounts behave like ‚Äúreal-time mirrors‚Äù of host folders.
üîé Are volumes like managed storage? Yes. Volumes are Docker-controlled storage resources with automatically assigned host paths. You can inspect or back them up, but Docker handles them for you.
üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Practice # ‚úÖ Step 1: Create a Volume # docker volume create mydata Check:
docker volume ls docker volume inspect mydata This creates a managed resource with its own storage path.
‚úÖ Step 2: Use the Volume in a Container # docker run -it --name voltest -v mydata:/data alpine mydata:/data means: mount Docker volume mydata into /data inside the container Inside, run: echo "Hello Volume!" > /data/hello.txt exit Now remove the container:
docker rm voltest Start a new container to access the same volume:
docker run -it -v mydata:/data alpine cat /data/hello.txt ‚úÖ You‚Äôll see the message again ‚Äî the data persisted.
‚úÖ Step 3: Use a Bind Mount # Create a folder on your host:
mkdir ~/docker-test echo "hello from host" > ~/docker-test/host.txt Run this container:
docker run -it -v ~/docker-test:/data alpine ls /data You should see host.txt. This is your local folder mounted into the container at runtime.
‚úÖ Key Syntax: What does mydata:/data mean? # This is used in the -v option:
mydata ‚Üí volume name (Docker-managed) /data ‚Üí path inside the container So it means: ‚ÄúMount the Docker volume mydata at /data in the container.‚Äù
For bind mounts, the syntax looks like:
-v /host/path:/container/path Example:
-v ~/project:/app This binds your host‚Äôs ~/project folder to the container‚Äôs /app directory.
üìç With volumes, Docker chooses the host path and manages it. With bind mounts, you define the host directory.
üîÑ Volume Sharing and Deletion # üß© Can a Volume Be Used by Multiple Containers? # ‚úÖ Yes. A Docker volume can be mounted into multiple containers ‚Äî they all share the same underlying data.
Example:
docker run -d --name c1 -v mydata:/shared alpine sleep 300 docker run -it --name c2 -v mydata:/shared alpine sh Both containers see the same files inside /shared.
You can even mount the same volume at different paths:
docker run -v mydata:/app1 alpine docker run -v mydata:/backup alpine üö´ What Happens If a Volume Is Deleted? # If a volume is in use, Docker will block deletion: docker volume rm mydata # ‚Üí Error: volume is in use If not in use, deleting the volume removes its data permanently. Anonymous volumes can be removed automatically when containers are deleted using --volumes. ‚ö†Ô∏è Concurrent Writes and Volume Safety # Docker does not coordinate concurrent access to volumes.
All containers writing to the same volume access the same underlying filesystem. Docker relies on the host OS filesystem to handle concurrent reads/writes. Scenario Safe? Notes Multiple containers reading ‚úÖ Yes Safe and common One writer, multiple readers ‚úÖ Usually Still depends on app-level logic Multiple writers ‚ùå Risky May lead to corruption or race issues üß† If you have multiple writers, use application-level coordination (e.g., file locks, DBs, queues).
üèÅ Checkpoint # You now know how to:
Create and manage Docker volumes Use volumes to persist data between containers Bind host folders into containers for development Distinguish clearly between volumes and bind mounts Share volumes across multiple containers Handle deletion scenarios and avoid data loss Understand Docker‚Äôs lack of built-in concurrency control üéâ Your containers are now capable of retaining, sharing, and coordinating data like full-scale applications.
üìÜ What‚Äôs Next? # Lesson 7: Docker Compose for Multi-Container Apps You‚Äôll learn how to define multi-service apps using a YAML file and bring up the entire app stack with one command.
Stay tuned!

title: Multiple Threads
content:
In our previous posts of using Selector for connection and communication (read/write) between server and clients, we only utilize only one thread. Multiplexing is highly efficient, but some time-consumed tasks would affect the overall performance.
In this post, I will mimic some functions from Netty which allocates tasks to different threads to improve the performance
Component # We will focus on the components in the server side
Boss # Boss runs under one thread Boss maintains one selector which only listens to ACCEPT events, in other words, boss is only responsible to accept client connections Worker # Worker runs in a separate thread Each worker has one selector which listens to READ and WRITE events After client’s connection, the newly created SocketChannel will be registered with one worker Architecture # Connect
A client connects to the server Boss accepts the connection and creates a SocketChannel Register
Boss registers the SocketChannel with one worker Worker starts to listen to READ and WRITE events from the newly registered channel Boss is decoupled with the channel Binding After registration, the SocketChannel is bound to the worker, and decoupled from the boss I/O operations including READ and WRITE are monitored and handled by the worker Implementation # Worker # @Getter @Setter @Slf4j public class Worker implements Runnable { private Thread thread; private Selector selector; private String name; private boolean start; public Worker(String name) { this.name = name; } public void register(SocketChannel sc) throws IOException { if (!start) { start = true; selector = Selector.open(); thread = new Thread(this, this.name); thread.start(); log.debug("Start selector and thread in {}", name); } sc.configureBlocking(false); sc.register(selector, SelectionKey.OP_READ, null); log.debug("Register client [{}] with {}", sc.getRemoteAddress(), name); } @Override public void run() { while (true) { try { log.debug("{} is listening...", name); selector.select(); Iterator<SelectionKey> iterator = selector.selectedKeys().iterator(); while (iterator.hasNext()) { SelectionKey key = iterator.next(); if (key.isReadable()) { SocketChannel sc = (SocketChannel) key.channel(); log.debug("Reading message from client [{}]", sc.getRemoteAddress()); ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.allocate(16); sc.read(buffer); buffer.flip(); ByteBufferReader.readAll("Message: ", buffer); } } } catch (IOException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } } } } Field Selector: Monitors and handles read/write operations from registered channels Thread: Task executor Method run(): Worker implements Runnable. This method only does one thing: selector.select(): Listens to channel’s events Handle events register(): First time call: Create the Selector Create and start the thread Register the channel with the Selector Problems: # Let’s look at the two main operations of worker:
monitor (selector.select()); registration (sc.register(selector, SelectionKey.OP_READ, null);) Monitor is executed by the worker thread, cause method register() is invoked by other thread, so registration is executed by other thread (boss).
While worker thread is blocked at line selector.select(), even though boss registers a new channel, the worker can’t start to monitor events from the new channel immediately until next round of monitor
Fix:
@Getter @Setter @Slf4j public class Worker implements Runnable { private Thread thread; private Selector selector; private String name; private boolean start; + private ConcurrentLinkedQueue<Runnable> tasks = new ConcurrentLinkedQueue<>(); public Worker(String name) { this.name = name; } public void register(SocketChannel sc) throws IOException { if (!start) { start = true; selector = Selector.open(); thread = new Thread(this, this.name); thread.start(); log.debug("Start selector and thread in {}", name); } sc.configureBlocking(false); - sc.register(selector, SelectionKey.OP_READ, null); - log.debug("Register client [{}] with {}", sc.getRemoteAddress(), name); + tasks.add(() -> { + try { + sc.register(selector, SelectionKey.OP_READ, null); + } catch (IOException e) { + throw new RuntimeException(e); + } + }); + selector.wakeup(); } @Override public void run() { while (true) { try { log.debug("{} is listening...", name); selector.select(); + if (!tasks.isEmpty()) { + tasks.poll().run(); + log.debug("Register client with {}", name); + } Iterator<SelectionKey> iterator = selector.selectedKeys().iterator(); while (iterator.hasNext()) { SelectionKey key = iterator.next(); iterator.remove(); if (key.isReadable()) { SocketChannel sc = (SocketChannel) key.channel(); log.debug("Reading message from client [{}]", sc.getRemoteAddress()); ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.allocate(16); ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.allocate(32); sc.read(buffer); buffer.flip(); ByteBufferReader.readAll("Message: ", buffer); } } } catch (IOException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } } } } I create a Queue as the bridge between two threads
Instead let other thread execute the registration, I add a Runnable task in the queue, and let the worker thread execute the registration
To fix the bug that the selector can’t immediately monitor newly registered channels while it is monitoring (blocked at selector.select()), I invoke method selector.wakeup() which unblocks the selector and let it continue to execute codes after adding the task to the queue,
Before handling events from selected keys, worker will first check if there are any registration tasks in the queue and do the registration if yes

title: TLS Handshake: Certificate Verify
content:
TLS Handshake: Certificate Verify # What is CertificateVerify? # During the TLS handshake, the server sends a CertificateVerify message to prove it owns the private key corresponding to the public key in its certificate. This step prevents attackers from using a stolen certificate without having the private key.
What Happens in This Step? # The server creates a hash of all previous handshake messages (called the “handshake transcript”). The server signs this hash using its private key. The server sends the CertificateVerify message to the client. It includes: The signature algorithm used (e.g., sha256+rsa_pss_rsae) The digital signature value Example:
###[ TLS Handshake - Certificate Verify ]### msgtype = certificate_verify msglen = 75 \sig \ |###[ TLS Digital Signature ]### | sig_alg = sha256+rsaepss | sig_len = 71 | sig_val = ... # The actual signature How Does the Client Verify It? # Extracts the public key from the server’s certificate. Decrypts the signature using the public key to recover the hash. Recomputes the hash of the handshake transcript using the specified algorithm. Compares the two hashes: If they match: ‚úÖ the server is verified. If they don‚Äôt match: ‚ùå the handshake fails. What If CertificateVerify Fails? # If the signature can’t be verified:
The client assumes the server is not trustworthy. The handshake is terminated immediately. No encrypted communication is established. Why It Matters # Even if a malicious actor has a server’s certificate, they cannot complete the handshake without the private key. CertificateVerify ensures that the server genuinely controls the private key, making the TLS connection secure.

title: Lesson 7: Docker Compose
content:
üß∞ Docker Mastery Course ‚Äì Lesson 7 # üß© Multi-Container Apps with Docker Compose (FastAPI + Redis) # Welcome to Lesson 7 of the Docker Mastery Course! In this lesson, you’ll learn how to orchestrate multi-container applications using Docker Compose, and build a working FastAPI + Redis system.
üéØ Goal # By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:
Define multiple services in a docker-compose.yml file Understand how Compose builds images and sets up networks Run, inspect, and tear down multi-service apps Understand container-to-container networking using service names üìò Concepts # What is Docker Compose? # Docker Compose is a tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications. It lets you:
Define your services in a YAML file Build images from a Dockerfile Spin up everything with a single command: docker-compose up Compose handles networking, service startup order, shared volumes, and more. It replaces the older --link method by automatically creating a dedicated user-defined bridge network where all services can communicate using their service names.
üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Practice: FastAPI + Redis # We‚Äôll build a simple web app that counts how many times a page is visited, using Redis as a backend store.
‚úÖ Step 1: Project Structure # docker-compose-fastapi/ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.py ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ requirements.txt ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Dockerfile ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ docker-compose.yml ‚úÖ Step 2: app.py # from fastapi import FastAPI import redis app = FastAPI() r = redis.Redis(host='redis', port=6379) @app.get('/') def read_root(): count = r.incr('hits') return {"message": f"Hello! This page has been viewed {count} times."} The host='redis' setting works because Compose creates a private DNS entry that maps the redis service name to its container IP. The port 6379 is Redis’s default internal port ‚Äî used inside the container for the Redis server to listen on. Since Redis is only accessed by the FastAPI container within the same Docker network, there’s no need to expose it publicly. ‚úÖ Step 3: requirements.txt # fastapi uvicorn[standard] redis ‚úÖ Step 4: Dockerfile # FROM python:3.11-slim WORKDIR /app COPY . . RUN pip install -r requirements.txt CMD ["uvicorn", "app:app", "--host", "0.0.0.0", "--port", "8000"] This sets up the FastAPI app to run on port 8000 inside the container. ‚úÖ Step 5: docker-compose.yml # version: '3' services: web: build: . ports: - "8000:8000" depends_on: - redis redis: image: redis:alpine The web service is built from the local Dockerfile. The redis service uses the official redis:alpine image from Docker Hub. depends_on ensures Redis starts before FastAPI. Compose automatically creates a dedicated network (e.g., docker-compose-fastapi_default) so the containers can talk to each other by service name. ‚úÖ Step 6: Run It # docker-compose up üîç What Happens Under the Hood # When you run docker-compose up, Docker Compose performs the following steps:
Parses the docker-compose.yml:
Identifies the defined services: web and redis Builds the image for web (if needed):
docker build -t docker-compose-fastapi-web . Pulls the image for redis (if not present):
docker pull redis:alpine Creates a dedicated Docker network:
docker network create docker-compose-fastapi_default Starts the containers:
docker run --name docker-compose-fastapi-web-1 --network docker-compose-fastapi_default -p 8000:8000 ... docker run --name docker-compose-fastapi-redis-1 --network docker-compose-fastapi_default ... Streams logs from both containers to the terminal for live monitoring.
Now, visit: http://localhost:8000
You should see the visit counter increase with each refresh.
To stop the application:
docker-compose down This command removes the containers and the associated network.
üß† Additional Notes # The number of containers created equals the number of services defined. In this case, two: one for web (FastAPI), and one for redis.
Redis‚Äôs 6379 port is its internal port, meaning it’s only used within the container. It‚Äôs not mapped to the host unless explicitly declared.
Since Redis is an internal service accessed only by FastAPI, there’s no need to expose this port to the host or external traffic.
Docker Compose sets up an internal network with DNS support, allowing service names like redis to be automatically resolved to their corresponding container IPs.
Compose uses your project folder name to generate default container and network names. For example:
Container: docker-compose-fastapi-web-1 Network: docker-compose-fastapi_default You can override this naming convention using the -p flag:
docker-compose -p myproject up Under the hood, Compose orchestrates the equivalent of docker build and docker run commands for each service.
üèÅ Checkpoint # You now know how to:
Build and run multi-container apps using Docker Compose Wire together FastAPI and Redis without exposing internal ports Use Compose‚Äôs built-in networking and service discovery Understand container lifecycle, port usage, and project naming behavior üéâ This sets the foundation for more complex, production-ready stacks.
üìÜ What‚Äôs Next? # Lesson 8: Logging, Healthchecks, and Container Lifecycle You‚Äôll learn how to monitor and manage the health and behavior of running containers.

title: TLS Handshake: Finished
content:
TLS Handshake: Finished # What is the Finished Message? # After the client verifies the server‚Äôs identity (with CertificateVerify), both the client and server send a Finished message. This message is the final step in the handshake that proves everything up to this point has not been tampered with.
Purpose # The Finished message ensures that:
All previous handshake steps were received and processed correctly. The handshake wasn’t modified or intercepted by an attacker. Both parties derived the same symmetric encryption key. Final Symmetric Key # By this point in the handshake:
Both the client and server have derived the same symmetric key using the earlier exchanged key share and supported group. This key is used to encrypt and decrypt all future HTTPS communication. The Finished message is the first message encrypted with this symmetric key. What Happens in This Step? # The sender (server or client) computes a hash of all previous handshake messages. This hash is then encrypted using the derived symmetric key. The resulting value is sent in the Finished message as verify_data. Example:
###[ TLS Handshake - Finished ]### msgtype = finished msglen = 32 vdata = ... # encrypted hash of all previous handshake messages How the Finished Message is Verified # When the recipient receives the Finished message:
They recompute the hash of all previous handshake messages. They decrypt the received verify_data using the symmetric key. They compare the decrypted hash with the recomputed one. If they match: ‚úÖ handshake is complete. If they don‚Äôt match: ‚ùå the connection is terminated. Why It Matters # The Finished message ensures the entire handshake is valid and hasn‚Äôt been tampered with. It‚Äôs a critical security step that wraps up the TLS handshake and marks the beginning of secure communication.

title: Lesson 8: Docker Logging, Healthchecks, and Container Lifecycle
content:
ü©∫ Docker Mastery Course ‚Äì Lesson 8 # üö¶ Logging, Healthchecks, and Container Lifecycle # Welcome to Lesson 8 of the Docker Mastery Course! In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to monitor and control container health and behavior using logging, healthchecks, and lifecycle management tools.
üéØ Goal # By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:
View and interpret container logs using Docker Define and use healthchecks to monitor container health Understand and manage container lifecycle states: created, running, exited, restarting üìò Concepts # 1. Viewing Logs # Docker captures stdout and stderr output from container processes. You can access logs with:
docker logs <container_name> Example:
docker logs docker-compose-fastapi-web-1 To follow logs in real time (like tail -f):
docker logs -f docker-compose-fastapi-web-1 2. Healthchecks # A healthcheck is a periodic command Docker runs inside the container to verify that the application is working properly.
In your Dockerfile:
HEALTHCHECK --interval=30s --timeout=10s --retries=3 \ CMD curl -f http://localhost:8000/ || exit 1 Or in docker-compose.yml:
services: web: build: . ports: - "8000:8000" depends_on: - redis healthcheck: test: ["CMD", "curl", "-f", "http://localhost:8000/"] interval: 10s timeout: 5s retries: 3 Docker marks the container with one of the following health statuses:
starting ‚Äì healthcheck hasn’t succeeded yet healthy ‚Äì healthcheck passed unhealthy ‚Äì healthcheck failed for the configured number of retries ‚úÖ Interpreting Healthcheck Results # Use this command to inspect a container‚Äôs health:
docker inspect --format='{{json .State.Health}}' <container> This uses a Go template to return only the .State.Health section in JSON format.
Example output:
{ "Status": "healthy", "FailingStreak": 0, "Log": [ ... ] } üß™ How curl -f Works # curl sends an HTTP request to the given address The -f flag causes curl to fail (exit code ‚â† 0) on HTTP 400+ status codes This ensures the healthcheck only passes when a successful response is returned 3. Container Lifecycle States # Docker containers transition through the following lifecycle states:
State Description created Container exists but hasn‚Äôt started running Container is executing exited Container has stopped paused Container is temporarily suspended restarting Container is restarting automatically To check a container‚Äôs state:
docker ps -a docker inspect <container> 4. Restart Policies # Restart policies determine how Docker responds to container failures.
Example in docker-compose.yml:
restart: always Options:
no ‚Äì Do not restart (default) on-failure ‚Äì Restart only if the container exits with a non-zero code always ‚Äì Restart regardless of exit status unless-stopped ‚Äì Always restart unless manually stopped üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Practice # Let‚Äôs apply a healthcheck to our FastAPI container.
‚úÖ Step 1: Update Compose and Dockerfile # üß± Updated Dockerfile # Ensure your Docker image includes curl, which is required for the healthcheck to function. Here‚Äôs the full Dockerfile:
FROM python:3.11-slim WORKDIR /app # Install curl for healthchecks RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y curl && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/* COPY . . RUN pip install -r requirements.txt CMD ["uvicorn", "app:app", "--host", "0.0.0.0", "--port", "8000"] Now, define the healthcheck in your docker-compose.yml:
services: web: build: . ports: - "8000:8000" depends_on: - redis healthcheck: test: ["CMD", "curl", "-f", "http://localhost:8000/"] interval: 10s timeout: 5s retries: 3 ‚úÖ Step 2: Rebuild and Start # docker-compose down docker-compose up --build ‚úÖ Step 3: Monitor Logs and Health # docker logs -f docker-compose-fastapi-web-1 docker inspect --format='{{json .State.Health}}' docker-compose-fastapi-web-1 | jq Note: jq is a powerful command-line JSON processor that beautifies and formats JSON output. You can install it with sudo apt install jq (Linux) or brew install jq (macOS).
This will show both the real-time logs and the container‚Äôs health status.
üß© FAQ # ‚ùì What‚Äôs the difference between Docker lifecycle state and health state? # Lifecycle state reflects Docker‚Äôs view of the container (e.g., running, exited, etc.) Health state is application-specific and only available if a healthcheck is defined A container can be running but still be unhealthy if its internal application fails the healthcheck ‚ùì Does Docker restart a container if its healthcheck fails? # No, not automatically Docker restart policies only apply if the container exits, not if it becomes unhealthy To react to healthcheck failure, you must use external logic or an orchestrator like Kubernetes üèÅ Checkpoint # You now know how to:
Monitor logs using docker logs Define and apply healthchecks in Dockerfiles and Compose files Inspect healthcheck results using templates Use restart policies effectively Distinguish between lifecycle states and health status You’re now prepared to build more observable and reliable Docker containers! ‚úÖ
üìÜ What‚Äôs Next? # Lesson 9: Environment Variables and Secrets Learn how to securely configure applications using .env files and Docker secrets.

title: Simulating HTTPS
content:
üìò Simulating HTTPS with TLS in FastAPI # In this lesson, we‚Äôll simulate a secure HTTPS server using FastAPI and a self-signed TLS certificate. This hands-on setup will help you understand how HTTPS works in practice and how certificates establish trust and enable encryption between clients and servers.
üîê What Is HTTPS (TLS)? # HTTPS = HTTP + TLS TLS (Transport Layer Security) encrypts communication between a client and a server. It protects data against eavesdropping, tampering, and man-in-the-middle attacks. TLS requires a certificate to authenticate the server’s identity and establish a secure connection. üõ†Ô∏è Step 1: Generate a Self-Signed Certificate # We‚Äôll use the openssl command to generate a self-signed certificate and private key. This setup is ideal for local development or learning environments.
üîç Command Breakdown
openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout key.pem -out cert.pem -days 365 -nodes Flag Description req -x509 Generate a certificate instead of a certificate signing request (CSR) -newkey rsa:2048 Create a new RSA private key with 2048-bit encryption -keyout key.pem Output path for the private key file -out cert.pem Output path for the public certificate file -days 365 Validity period of the certificate (365 days) -nodes No password encryption on the private key (simplifies local testing) üìå When prompted, enter localhost as the Common Name (CN) so the browser recognizes it as a match.
üöÄ Step 2: Create a Simple FastAPI App # create a new python project https:
mkdir https cd https python3 -m venv venv source venv/bin/activate pip install fastapi uvicorn touch main.py Paste below code to main.py:
from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") def read_root(): return {"message": "Hello over HTTPS!"} ‚öôÔ∏è Step 3: Launch FastAPI with HTTPS # Use uvicorn to run your FastAPI app with HTTPS enabled by specifying the key and certificate files.
üîç Command Breakdown
uvicorn main:app --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8443 --ssl-keyfile=key.pem --ssl-certfile=cert.pem Option Description main:app Path to the FastAPI app object (app) in main.py --host 0.0.0.0 Listen on all network interfaces (use 127.0.0.1 for localhost only) --port 8443 Use port 8443 (commonly used for HTTPS in dev environments) --ssl-keyfile Path to the private key (key.pem) --ssl-certfile Path to the public certificate (cert.pem) Once the server is running, navigate to:
https://localhost:8443 ‚úÖ A browser security warning will appear. This is expected because the certificate is self-signed and not trusted by default.
üß™ Step 4: Test HTTPS with curl # To skip certificate verification, use the -k (insecure) option:
curl -k https://localhost:8443 ‚úÖ Expected output:
{"message": "Hello over HTTPS!"} üîç Step 5: Inspect TLS Handshake with OpenSSL # To view TLS handshake details:
openssl s_client -connect localhost:8443 This command outputs:
TLS version (e.g., TLS 1.2 or 1.3) Cipher suite used Certificate details and validity period You should be able to see the server certificate, which is the certificate in file cert.pem

title: Lesson 9: Docker Env
content:
üîê Docker Mastery Course ‚Äì Lesson 9 # üß™ Environment Variables and Secrets # Welcome to Lesson 9 of the Docker Mastery Course! In this lesson, you’ll learn how to inject and manage configuration settings and secrets in your containers using environment variables and .env files.
üéØ Goal # By the end of this lesson, you will be able to:
Use environment variables to configure container behavior Load configuration from .env files Access environment variables inside a FastAPI application Recognize the risks of storing secrets in environment variables üìò Concepts # 1. Why Use Environment Variables? # Environment variables allow you to pass dynamic configuration into containers without modifying application code. They’re commonly used for:
Debug or logging flags Database connection strings API keys and service URLs While they are convenient, they are not recommended for storing sensitive secrets.
2. Methods for Passing Environment Variables # ‚úÖ a. Inline via the Command Line # docker run -e DEBUG=true myapp ‚úÖ b. Defined in docker-compose.yml # services: web: image: myapp environment: - DEBUG=true - DB_URL=postgres://user:pass@host:5432/db ‚úÖ c. Loaded from a .env File # Create a file named .env:
DEBUG=true DB_URL=postgres://user:pass@host:5432/db Then reference it in your Compose file:
services: web: env_file: - .env Docker Compose will automatically load and inject these variables into the container environment.
3. Accessing Environment Variables in Python # In a FastAPI application, use the os module to read environment variables:
import os GREETING = os.getenv("GREETING", "Hello") # Defaults to "Hello" if not set This ensures your app behaves predictably even if the variable is missing.
4. Are Environment Variables Secure? # Not entirely:
They are stored in plain text within container metadata Accessible via docker inspect, docker exec env, and even logs in some cases ‚úÖ Use environment variables for general configuration ‚ùå Avoid them for storing sensitive secrets like passwords or tokens
5. Safer Alternatives for Secrets # For handling secrets securely, consider using:
Docker Swarm Secrets ‚Äì encrypted and stored securely (not supported in plain Compose) Kubernetes Secrets ‚Äì base64-encoded and supported by orchestrators AWS Secrets Manager or SSM Parameter Store Bind mounts ‚Äì mount a file containing secrets to the container and read at runtime üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Practice: Using Env Vars in FastAPI # ‚úÖ Step 1: Update app.py # Modify your FastAPI application to read from an environment variable:
from fastapi import FastAPI import redis import os app = FastAPI() r = redis.Redis(host='redis', port=6379) GREETING = os.getenv("GREETING", "Hello") @app.get('/') def read_root(): count = r.incr('hits') return {"message": f"{GREETING}! This page has been viewed {count} times."} ‚úÖ Step 2: Create a .env File # Add the following content to a new file named .env in your project root:
GREETING=Hi ‚úÖ Step 3: Update docker-compose.yml # Ensure your Compose file includes the .env reference:
version: '3' services: web: build: . ports: - "8000:8000" depends_on: - redis env_file: - .env healthcheck: test: ["CMD", "curl", "-f", "http://localhost:8000/"] interval: 10s timeout: 5s retries: 3 redis: image: redis:alpine ‚úÖ Step 4: Rebuild and Run Your Containers # docker-compose down docker-compose up --build Then visit http://localhost:8000 to confirm that the greeting reflects the value in your .env file.
‚úÖ Step 5: Customize and Test # Change the .env file to:
GREETING=Howdy Rebuild and run:
docker-compose up --build Check that the output message updates accordingly.
üß© Tip: Viewing Environment Variables in a Running Container # To list the environment variables inside a running container:
docker exec docker-compose-fastapi-web-1 env To view full metadata:
docker inspect docker-compose-fastapi-web-1 ‚ö†Ô∏è Be cautious ‚Äî this output may expose sensitive values.
üèÅ Checkpoint # You now know how to:
Configure containers using environment variables and .env files Access those variables from inside a FastAPI application Understand the limitations of env vars for secure secrets Safely test and modify runtime behavior using Docker Compose You’re one step closer to building production-grade, configurable Docker containers. ‚úÖ
üìÜ What‚Äôs Next? # Lesson 10: Multi-Stage Builds and Image Optimization Learn how to reduce Docker image size and accelerate builds using multi-stage Dockerfiles.

title: Lesson 10: Docker Multi-Stage
content:
üöÄ Docker Mastery Course ‚Äì Lesson 10 # üß∞ Multi-Stage Builds and Image Optimization # Welcome to Lesson 10 of the Docker Mastery Course! In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to optimize Docker images using multi-stage builds ‚Äî a powerful technique for separating build-time and runtime concerns.
üéØ Goal # By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:
Understand what multi-stage builds are and why they matter Reduce image size and improve security Apply multi-stage techniques to your FastAPI application üìò Concepts # 1. Why Optimize Your Docker Images? # A typical Dockerfile may include:
Source code Build tools like pip, gcc, curl Temporary files such as .env, tests/, and caches This leads to bloated images that are slower to build, ship, and run ‚Äî and can pose security risks.
2. What Is a Multi-Stage Build? # Multi-stage builds let you define multiple FROM instructions within a single Dockerfile. Each FROM starts a new, isolated stage. You can build your application in one stage, then copy only the necessary output into a clean, minimal final image.
Benefits include:
üöÄ Smaller images ‚Äì faster pulls, deployments, and fewer vulnerabilities üîê Cleaner environments ‚Äì no leftover dev tools or unused files üí° Simplicity ‚Äì one Dockerfile for both dev and production üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Practice: Apply Multi-Stage Build to FastAPI # Let‚Äôs refactor your Dockerfile using a multi-stage approach.
‚úÖ Step 1: Current Dockerfile (Before Optimization) # FROM python:3.11-slim WORKDIR /app RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y curl && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/* COPY . . RUN pip install -r requirements.txt CMD ["uvicorn", "app:app", "--host", "0.0.0.0", "--port", "8000"] üîç This Dockerfile installs dependencies and runs the app in a single stage ‚Äî meaning everything (even temporary tools) ends up in the final image.
‚úÖ Step 2: Refactored Multi-Stage Dockerfile # # Stage 1: Builder FROM python:3.11-slim AS builder WORKDIR /app COPY . . RUN pip install --user -r requirements.txt # Stage 2: Runtime FROM python:3.11-slim WORKDIR /app RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y curl && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/* COPY --from=builder /root/.local /root/.local COPY app.py . ENV PATH="/root/.local/bin:$PATH" CMD ["uvicorn", "app:app", "--host", "0.0.0.0", "--port", "8000"] ‚úÖ Only app.py is copied into the final image ‚Äî not requirements.txt or other development files. This reduces bloat and minimizes the risk of leaking build-time artifacts into production.
‚úÖ Step 3: Build and Run # To build the image using Compose:
docker-compose down docker-compose up --build üìù By default, Docker and Compose use the last stage of the Dockerfile as the final image.
‚úÖ Step 4: Validate the Optimization # Let‚Äôs demonstrate the benefit of multi-stage builds with a direct comparison:
Check what files are included in the image:
docker exec -it docker-compose-fastapi-web-1 sh ls /app ‚úÖ You should only see app.py ‚Äî not requirements.txt, .env, or any development files. This demonstrates that only explicitly copied files are present in the final image.
üí° Common Questions # ‚ùì Is docker-compose build automatically triggered in docker-compose up? # Not by default. You must explicitly add --build:
docker-compose up --build Without --build, Compose uses any previously built image.
‚ùì Is each FROM a separate stage? # ‚úÖ Yes! Each FROM starts a new build stage. You can name stages using AS and refer to earlier ones using COPY --from=stage_name.
üèÅ Checkpoint # You now know how to:
Split Dockerfiles into build and runtime stages Produce leaner and more secure Docker images Apply multi-stage builds to real-world FastAPI apps You‚Äôve leveled up your Docker skills significantly! ‚úÖ
üìÜ What‚Äôs Next? # Lesson 11: .dockerignore and Build Context Learn how .dockerignore and build context affect your image content and build performance.

title: Lesson 11: Docker Context & `.dockerignore`
content:
üóÇÔ∏è Docker Mastery Course ‚Äì Lesson 11 # üì¶ Build Context and .dockerignore # Welcome to Lesson 11 of the Docker Mastery Course! In this lesson, you’ll learn how to use the .dockerignore file to optimize the build context, improve build speed, and avoid leaking sensitive files into your Docker images.
üéØ Goal # By the end of this lesson, you’ll be able to:
Understand what Docker’s build context is and why it matters Use a .dockerignore file to reduce build size and improve security Prevent unnecessary or sensitive files from being copied into Docker images üìò Concepts # 1. What Is Build Context? # When you run:
docker build . Docker sends everything in the current directory (and subdirectories) to the Docker daemon. This sent content is called the build context.
Any files sent in the build context can be referenced in COPY or ADD commands inside the Dockerfile.
Problems with a large build context:
Slower builds Higher risk of accidentally leaking files like .env or .git Larger Docker images if COPY . . is used 2. What Is .dockerignore? # The .dockerignore file tells Docker to exclude specific files or directories from the build context ‚Äî similar to how .gitignore works with Git.
Example .dockerignore:
Dockerfile docker-compose.yml .env .dockerignore ‚úÖ This makes builds faster and images cleaner and safer when using broad COPY commands.
üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Practice: Optimize Build Context in docker-compose-fastapi # ‚úÖ Step 1: Create a .dockerignore File # In the root of your docker-compose-fastapi project, create a .dockerignore file with the following:
__pycache__/ *.pyc *.pyo *.log .env venv/ tests/ .git/ .dockerignore This prevents test data, logs, Python caches, secrets, and Git metadata from being sent to the Docker daemon.
‚úÖ Step 2: Use a Single-Stage Dockerfile # FROM python:3.11-slim WORKDIR /app RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y curl && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/* COPY . . RUN pip install -r requirements.txt CMD ["uvicorn", "app:app", "--host", "0.0.0.0", "--port", "8000"] This Dockerfile copies the entire project directory using COPY . ., so without .dockerignore, all files would end up in the image.
‚úÖ Step 3: Build and Run the Image # Build the image and start the container:
docker-compose down docker-compose up --build This uses the Dockerfile and .dockerignore file together to build a leaner image.
‚úÖ Step 4: Inspect Files Inside the Container # Open a shell session in the container:
docker exec -it docker-compose-fastapi-web-1 sh ls -a /app ‚úÖ You should see only essential files like:
app.py requirements.txt ‚ùå You should not see:
.env .dockerignore Dockerfile docker-compose.yml ‚úÖ Step 5: (Optional) Check Build Context Size # To observe how much data is being sent:
DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0 docker build . Look for a line like:
Sending build context to Docker daemon 5.12kB ‚úÖ The smaller this number, the better your .dockerignore is working.
üèÅ Checkpoint # You now understand:
What the Docker build context is How to use .dockerignore to exclude unnecessary files How to verify that only intended files are copied into the container This will help you build smaller, faster, and more secure Docker images. ‚úÖ
üìÜ What‚Äôs Next? # Lesson 12: Add PostgreSQL to FastAPI Learn how to connect your FastAPI app to a PostgreSQL container using Docker Compose.

title: Tcp Socket
content:
What Is a Socket? # Server socket listens to a port Normally, a server runs on a specific computer and has a socket that is bound to a specific port number. The server just waits, listening to the socket for a client to make a connection request.
Cient connects to the server with server ip and port On the client-side: The client knows the hostname of the machine on which the server is running and the port number on which the server is listening. To make a connection request, the client tries to rendezvous with the server on the server’s machine and port. The client also needs to identify itself to the server so it binds to a local port number that it will use during this connection. This is usually assigned by the system.
Server accepts connection and creates a new socket If everything goes well, the server accepts the connection. Upon acceptance, the server gets a new socket bound to the same local port and also has its remote endpoint set to the address and port of the client. It needs a new socket so that it can continue to listen to the original socket for connection requests while tending to the needs of the connected client.
Socket is successfully created on client On the client side, if the connection is accepted, a socket is successfully created and the client can use the socket to communicate with the server.
The client and server can now communicate by writing to or reading from their sockets. [1]
Examples # Create Sockets # Server
public class Server_ { public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException { // A server socket listens to port 8888 ServerSocket serverSocket = new ServerSocket(8888); // The program is blocked here waiting for client connecting Socket socket = serverSocket.accept(); // Your business logic ... // Close both sockets to release system resource socket.close(); serverSocket.close(); } } First we create a ServerSocket listening to port 8888 Before accepting any connections, the program is blocked at line Socket socket = serverSocket.accept(); A client requests to connect to the server. After the server accepts the request, a new socket will be created in the server After your business logic, close the socket and server socket to release system resources Client
public class Client_ { public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException { // Create a new socket and connect to port 8888 on the server Socket socket = new Socket(InetAddress.getByName("<host-name>");, 8888); // Your business logic ... // Close the socket to release system resource socket.close(); } } First we create a socket connecting to port 8888 of the host Once the connection is successfully created, a socket will be created After your business logic, close the socket to release system resources Upload File from Client to Server # Client
public class Client_ { public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException { // Create a new socket and connect to a specific port of the server Socket socket = new Socket(InetAddress.getLocalHost(), 8888); // Read file from disk String filePath = "/path/to/the/file"; FileInputStream bis = new FileInputStream(filePath); byte[] data = inputStreamToByteArray(bis); bis.close(); System.out.println("Client reads a file from disk"); // Send byte data of the file to the server OutputStream os = socket.getOutputStream(); os.write(data); // You need to shut down the output stream, otherwise the server will hang up // It's a signal let server know that you're done sending data // TODO: What's the corresponding TCP packet for this? socket.shutdownOutput(); System.out.println("Client uploads a file to server"); // Close streams and socket os.close(); socket.close(); } } Client reads a file in the disk to a FileInputStream, and invoke an utility method inputStreamToByteArray to convert InputStream to a byte array Then client writes the byte data into its output stream and sends it to the server Close all streams and socket to release system resources Utility method:
public class InputStreamUtil { public static byte[] inputStreamToByteArray(InputStream is) throws IOException { byte[] buf = new byte[1024]; ByteArrayOutputStream bos = new ByteArrayOutputStream(); int len; while((len = is.read(buf)) != -1) { bos.write(buf, 0, len); } byte[] result = bos.toByteArray(); bos.close(); return result; } } The utility method creates a ByteArrayOutputStream as a buffer to store data read from the input stream Contantly reads data from the input stream and writes the data into the ByteArrayOutputStream Invokes toByteArray method to get a byte array holding the data Server
public class Server_ { public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException { // A server socket waits for requests to come in over the network. ServerSocket serverSocket = new ServerSocket(8888); // Listens to a connection and accepts it. Returns a new socket Socket socket = serverSocket.accept(); // Read data from input stream InputStream is = socket.getInputStream(); byte[] data = inputStreamToByteArray(is); System.out.println("Server received file uploaded from client"); // Save the file to local disk String filePath = "/path/to/save/the/file"; BufferedOutputStream bos = new BufferedOutputStream(new FileOutputStream(filePath)); bos.write(data); bos.close(); // Close streams and socket is.close(); socket.close(); serverSocket.close(); } } Server socket listens to port 8888 in local host Creates a new socket to accept connection from the client Reads data from socket’s input stream Writes byte data to disk through FileOutputStream Close all streams and sockets to release system resources

title: Decorator Pattern in Java IO
content:
Node Streams (Low-Level Streams) # Definition:
Node Streams connect directly with the source of the data They read data from or write data to a specific location (like a file, memory, or network socket). Example: FileInputStream is a node stream that reads byte data from a file.
File file = new File("example.txt"); FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(file); Here, FileInputStream is directly reading the bytes from the file “example.txt”. It’s a direct connection between the Java program and the file.
Processing Streams (High-Level Streams) # Definition:
Processing Streams are built on top of node streams to provide additional functionality, like buffering, filtering, reading objects, etc. They don’t write or read data directly to or from data source, but delegate this job to node streams. Example: BufferedInputStream is a processing stream that adds buffering capabilities to another input stream, such as FileInputStream.
FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream("example.txt"); BufferedInputStream bis = new BufferedInputStream(fis); BufferedInputStream does not connect directly to the file. Instead, it wraps the FileInputStream and adds buffering to it. When you read from a BufferedInputStream, it retrieves data from the buffer, and when the buffer is empty, it reads another large chunk of data from the FileInputStream and fills the buffer. This minimizes the number of interactions with the file system, which is much slower than reading from a buffer in memory.
Combining Node and Processing Streams # Typically, you chain processing streams together to get both their benefits. For instance, wrapping a FileInputStream with a BufferedInputStream.
File file = new File("example.txt"); InputStream is = new BufferedInputStream(new FileInputStream(file)); ... is.close(); In this example, we use FileInputStream to connect to the file and BufferedInputStream to add buffering. The data still comes from the file, but it passes through the buffer, which can be read from more quickly than the file.
Decorator Pattern in Java IO Stream # Component (Node Stream) # Definition: The component is the primary or underlying object that has the original behavior, which is to read data from data source for node streams. In Java IO: FileInputStream and FileReader are example of components. They provide the basic functionality for byte and character stream handling. Decorator (Processing Stream) # Definition: Decorators implement or extend the same interface as the component they are going to decorate. They compose the instance of component and provide an enhanced interface with added responsibilities.- In Java IO: BufferedInputStream, BufferedOutputStream, BufferedReader, and BufferedWriter are examples of decorators. They add buffering to the streams they decorate. Key Features of Decorator # Delegation: The decorator delegates the work to the component it decorates and then adds its own behavior before or after delegating. This is a key feature because it means the decorator itself doesn’t handle the primary operations; it relies on the component to do so.
